data.title: Are you ‚Äúover‚Äù GTA? (Or, other franchises you used to like but just got over/taste changed/ whatever)
data.meta_description: I do miss the days where you could be a little more creative with missions like in GTA3 for example, now it seems like things are a bit more on rails. I...
data.text:
samoscratch

Nov 25, 2017

2,872

Thursday at 2:52 PM

#101

I do miss the days where you could be a little more creative with missions like in GTA3 for example, now it seems like things are a bit more on rails. I also feel like the satire was a bit more biting in the older titles. Open worlds are also not so unusual these days so it doesn't feel as special.

So I'm not really interested in GTA6 or anything they make next.

I've enjoyed them all so far, and I'm excited for 6. For me as long as they keep making high quality single player stories I'm in.

#108

Yeah, GTA IV was the beginning of the end for me. A massive change in controls coupled with removal of all the side missions that would get me comfortable with everything, i.e., the taxi/ambulance/police missions. Put an hour or so into and never touched it since.

Did play through almost all of GTA V though but it really only solidified that decision. A very shallow world with a short and uninspiring single player campaign that did nothing for me. Pretty clear the focus on all on the online stuff and can't say I blame them given how much of a cash cow it is.

USA

Thursday at 3:39 PM

#114

I think GTAV is the only one in the series where the gameplay felt good enough all-around to keep me coming back periodically over the years since its initial release.

I am looking forward to GTA6 on that front (gameplay), but I admit that GTA's storytelling has never really been my thing. I think I appreciate them chasing a tone that largely felt distinct for a while after GTA III, but the various copycats and even its own internal storytelling just kinda felt like it caved under its own weight a bit.

RDR2's storytelling was fantastic though, and if Rockstar has found a way to take that kind of tack and apply it to a modern setting and kinda ditch the mega cynicism of the previous GTAs and manage to strike a good balance of parody and humane drama without going so, so, so sardonic, then I think GTA finally fully realizes itself with 6 for me. So I'm excited, but I say that as someone who only ever really loved the gameplay of V and never really loved the storytelling of any of them.

#118

Fuck GTA and I don't even want another RDR for now. I'll play GTA 6 when it's absurdly cheap or on some sub if I ever feel the need and not follow the story probably, just do shit until I get bored.

Having played 2, 3 and VC, I skipped high school to go rent San Andreas and play it all morning with some friends at a rehearsal place and then all weekend at home.

I got an Xbox 360 and more or less back into videogames full steam again after getting hyped with some GTA 4 trailers and shit. The game didn't deliver but I finished it. And loved my 360 and eventual ps3.

Got hyped as hell with RDR and it was very nice and even played online with friends.

Still got GTA 5 day one on PS3 and suffered it until the end of the story and many side activities. Much better than 4 in everything but the Euphoria engine use.

RDR2 was the best game by Rockstar I played so far when I got it day one and played for months (also even online). Had my fill.

Not anymore. Saw the trailer for 6, zero hype, found it disgusting even. Much more exciting games to look forward to personally.

Thursday at 4:01 PM

#119

When I was a kid, I played and enjoyed greatly GTA2, GTA3 and GTA: Vice City. But San Andreas didn't captivate me enough, and after that I fell out of gaming, so missed 4 and 5.

I do want to play GTA6 eventually, since it likely be an important piece of media, but probably when it is ~$10-15. Honestly outside of production values and sheer scale, I don't really expect them to do anything super interesting, so if there is something really innovating, I might change my mind.

GTA5 came out almost 11 years ago. For perspective, there was 7 mainline Asscreed games(8 if you include Rogue) since it originally came out and there will be another when Asscreed Shadows comes out later this year.

I know 5 is a money maker but I'm so fucking tired of it.

#121

I adore them. I'm hoping for something closer to IV than V, though. The first trailer didn't give me much hope, as it just looks like a continuation of V's vibe, but we'll see once we finally start to get more of a glimpse at the game's overall tone and gameplay. As much as I enjoyed V, I think they have more potential doing a somewhat serious crime drama over something a lot wackier. Sam Houser always said he hadn't seen The Sopranos because he knew he would start trying to emulate it, and although I understand his perspective, I actually wish he would. That's the kind of tone I'd love a GTA game to have.

For GTA, the last one I liked was San Andreas. Haven't cared about the series at all since then, so I'd say I'm over it. But 1, 3, and SA got a lot of play out of me when I was a kid.

Mortal Kombat is another franchise I used to love, all the way up until 9. 9 was awesome, the absolute peak of the (mainline) series for me. X started letting me down during the roster-reveal process. Most of my favs weren't there, and I didn't like the new characters either. Still, I bought it randomly when I saw it on sale for like $20 later. Played through it once with Sub-Zero and never touched the game again. Didn't like the boost in speed X had over 9, too, on top of the disappointing roster.

Honestly, the only thing I want from MK now is a port of Shaolin Monks.

Absolutely not.

I thought GTAIV was pretty crap, but GTAV is a brilliant game, that I've played through twice, and could replay again. It's a standout title alongside RDR2 in the open world action game genre, and I've never felt the boredom or feeling of gameplay being chores in them.

And I've never understood people comparing games like the mediocre Saints Row games with games like GTAV.

The only issue I have with the series is that GTAVI doesn't have a PC version announced, and you can count on a PC version being needed to get an acceptable framerate for the game.

#129

Only ever played actually GTAV (played GTAIV occasionally at friends' houses, but that was just taking turns killing people and trying to stay alive for as long as possible), and I actually enjoyed it and played the story all the way through like 3 times, but I came back like a year later and just moving the characters around felt absolutely awful to the point I wondered how I played it so much in the first place. Played some missions and the insanely restrictive design really started to bother me (it really feels like you turn left when the game wants you to turn right and back to the last checkpoint). It completely killed any desire I had to play RDR2, which from all I've read about it doesn't change any of those issues, and as a consequence I also don't really care about GTAVI at all. I'm sure it will sell gangbusters but only way I would play it is if I got it for free.

yallasama

Dec 7, 2022

353

Thursday at 5:24 PM

#130

Definitely still some love there, but they have to win me back over. 4 and 5 both had big flaws that kept me from enjoying them outside of doing the story and the occasional side mission, just driving around etc. Mafia is still the best 3D open world crime and car game, but by the looks of it GTA6 finally might become what I envisioned GTA always could and should've been: more grounded, less reliant on the parody on America and silly jokes, more authentic and real-to-life in its driving, the city it's based on, the things you have to do and can do to live life, complete missions in all kinds of creative ways, the police response, jail and or prison system and less of a rags to riches story, which GTA5 partially already did. Playing as a woman should also really add a new element to the game. The only way this game could really let me down if it's still the same old GTA, but more realistic graphically and actual life-like gore. I don't need to see intestines, shredded arms and other body parts accurately reacting to being hit with a bullet / sharp object etc. That could really turn me off, though I might just drive around the city since it's the only game I expect to have next gen graphics in an open world where you can just explore any part you want as you would in real life.

I was 'over it' because they only had 1 new game in about 15 years.

It's this, plus their refusal to evolve their humor past early 00's edgelord, plus their decision to gut the heist stuff out of 5's story and transplant it to GTA Online really soured me on the entire thing. I'm interested to see what they pull off in 6, but in comparison to my excitement for, say, San Andreas or 4? Not even close.

And btw I only play through the single player portion.

Thursday at 6:56 PM

#139

I've always found GTA kind of cringe and juvenile. I played bits of Vice City, San Andreas and GTA4 at friends' houses as a teenager. I had fun, but never enough to want to get them myself. GTA5 was the first to release while I was an adult. Once again, played a fair bit at friends' houses but it felt very obvious by then it wasn't a game for me beyond a social thing to mess around with.

I fully respect the level of polish and depth of the systems they have though, so I'm looking forward to GTA6 to hear people talk about it (especially Digital Foundry). But it would take a lot to convince me to buy it. I won't say never though. I quite like RDR1 and 2, so Rockstar definitely has potential to appeal to my tastes. It would need some more mature writing from them, though.

As for other series, I played every COD from COD4 through MW3 (the original) quite religiously. I mostly played them for their campaigns and various horde/zombies modes, and only rarely dabbled in the multiplayer. I felt Infinity Ward in particular were great at designing action set-pieces, so that was the main draw for me. Tried BLOPS2 and got burnt out halfway through the campaign and never finished it, which is a rarity for me as I almost always force myself to finish games. Haven't touched a COD since, beyond playing a lot of split-screen Zombies for Infinite Warfare with my housemate a few years ago. Do they still make split-screen for those? That's probably the only thing I'd come back for now.

Similar thing happened with AC. Played 1 through Revelations and really enjoyed them, but was getting a little fatigued on the formula by the end of Revelations. Started AC3 and knew within 2 hours I just had no interest in continuing. Gave the game away, and then Black Flag came out and looked awesome, so I picked up a cheap second-hand copy of AC3 to try again. I couldn't bring myself to skip AC3 and go straight to Black Flag, but I also couldn't bring myself to play AC3 either. Never ended up touching it, and then reviews for the next few games didn't seem great so I just never came back to the series. Considered jumping back in on either Origins or Odyssey multiple times, and then I hear about how bloated they are and I know that's my least favourite type of open world game. If I'm going to do that to myself, I'd much rather replay The Witcher 3 and at least know I'm getting a more interesting world to immerse myself in.

Other than those, sports games. I played a lot of FIFA, NBA 2K and Madden NFL, but haven't touched any of them in over 8 years, except for the very rare occasion at a friends' house (and even then, not since 2020).

I still like GTA, but I loved it as a teenager. GTA San Andreas was peak hype for me, but I continue to play all the mainline games and fully expect to play GTA VI as well (will probably wait to get it on sale though).

Other series I used to like and am no longer into:

- Batman Arkham series ‚Äî played and enjoyed the first two and decided I had had enough

- Assassin's Creed series ‚Äî enjoyed the first game, played a bit of II and fell off after that. Many years later, I tried IV, but quickly got bored and decided the series isn't for me anymore.

- New Super Mario Bros series ‚Äî I've played all of them and each one was a disappointment compared to Super Mario World and Super Mario Bros 3. I was ready to give up on the "New" games, but Nintendo had a return to form with Super Mario Bros Wonder
